flow.descriptionCdata:
c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.2bb5cec3-d6f6-4d80-9006-6d1c8edcf663.description=
This operation executes PowerShell scripts on a given host.

Inputs\:
    host - The hostname or IP address of the PowerShell host. If you specify this input then you should not specify URI and shellURI.
Default value\: localhost
    URI - Specifies a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) that defines the connection endpoint for the interactive session. 
Value format\: \://\:/
Example\: http\://exch2010CAS1/Powershell?serializationLevel\=Full
    shellURI - Gets the Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) of the shell that is launched when the connection is made.
Example\: http\://schemas.microsoft.com/powershell/Microsoft.Exchange
    username - The username to use when connecting to the server.
Value format\: username@domain or domain\username.
    password - The password to use when connecting to the server.
    configurationName - Specifies the session configuration that is used for the new PSSession. If you specify only the configuration name, the following schema URI is prepended\: http\://schemas.microsoft.com/powershell. Use Microsoft.PowerShell32 to force x32 PowerShell version on x64 machines.
    authType - Specifies the mechanism that is used to authenticate the user's credentials. 
Valid values\: Default, Basic, Negotiate, NegotiateWithImplicitCredential, Credssp, Digest and Kerberos. (case-insensitive)
Default value\: Default
    connectionTimeout - Determines how long the client computer waits for the remote session connection to be established. When the interval expires, the command to establish the connection fails. Enter a positive value in milliseconds.
Default value\: 180000 (3 minutes).
    scriptTimeout - Determines how long the client computer waits for the PowerShell script to be executed. When the interval expires, the operation fails. Enter a positive value in milliseconds. An empty value means no time-out; the script execution continues indefinitely.
    useSSL - If true, the operation uses the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) protocol to establish a connection to the remote computer. By default, SSL is not used. WS-Management encrypts all Windows PowerShell content transmitted over the network. UseSSL is an additional protection that sends the data across an HTTPS connection instead of an HTTP connection. Default port for SSL is 5986.
Default value\: false
    skipCACheck - Indicates whether, when connecting over HTTPS, the client does not validate that the server certificate is signed by a trusted certificate authority (CA).
Default value\: true
    skipCNCheck - Indicates whether the certificate common name (CN) of the server and the hostname of the server are not checked for being the same.
Default value\: true
    port - Specifies the network port on the remote computer that is used for this connection. To connect to a remote computer, the remote computer must be listening on the port that the connection uses. The default ports are 5985 (the WinRM port for HTTP) and 5986 (the WinRM port for HTTPS).
    keepSessionAlive - If true, the operation will not close the PowerShell runspace (i.e. the PSSession in case of remote connections ) created during the execution and returns the runspaceID as the result of the operation. Actually the PowerShell runspace is saved in the OO session and can be used in other operations using the runspaceID result of previous operation.
Default value\: false
    enablePiping - If true the operation enables piping the way PowerShell does. This input should be used only when keepSessionAlive input is true. First time the piped objects are null and the scope is to save the objects resulted from the PowerShell script execution. Next time the piped objects can be refered in the script as "$_" objects.
Default value\: false
Example\: First, run "Get-Service" script with enablePiping\=true and keepSessionAlive\=true, then run the script  "Select-Object -property name,displayname,status|where-object {$_.Name -lt "C"}" with enablePiping\=true keepSessionAlive\=true. Observe the use of "$_".
    runspaceID - If not empty, the operation will search the OO session for keys which equal the runspaceID. If the operation finds the runspace specified by the runspaceID it tries to use it and does not create another PowerShell runspace with provided inputs. If the runspace exists but is broken or unavailable the operation uses its authentication parameters and tries to reconnect and recreate the PowerShell runspace. Please note that the operation will use the connection parameters of the runspace identified by runspaceID, not the values provided as user inputs. The operation will take into consideration the connection inputs (i.e. host, username, password, authType, useSSL, etc.) provided by user only if the runspaceID does not exist in the OO session.
    modules - A list of PowerShell modules to load after the PowerShell connection is established. Each value from the list specifies the name of the module to import. Enter the name of the module or the name of a file in the module, such as a .psd1, .psm1, .dll, or ps1 file. File paths are optional. Wildcards are not permitted. Specify only the module name whenever possible. When you specify a file name, only the members that are implemented in that file are imported. If the module contains other files, they are not imported, and you might be missing important members of the module. The list of modules should be separated by comma "," delimiter.
Example\: FailoverClusters
    snapins - A list of PowerShell snapins to load after the PowerShell connection is established. Each value from the list specifies the name of a registered snapin (i.e. the Name, not the AssemblyName or ModuleName).
Example\: Microsoft.Exchange.Management.PowerShell.E2010
    script - The script to execute on the PowerShell host. If you want to execute a script from file just provide the file path.
Example\:c\:\PowerShellScripts\GetHost.ps1
    cmdlet - The name of the PowerShell cmdlet to invoke. If the cmdlet has additional parameters, please provide them as inputs to the operation. If the parameter has the same name as one of the operation's inputs just prefix it with "_". This input is intended to be used together with the PowerShell wizard so please use the script input whenever it's possible.
    returnTable - If true, the operation will return a table containing a row for each PSObject that the script emits. The table's columns represent the properties of these PSObjects, in the propertyNamepropertyValue format. If false the operation returns a string representation of the result similar to the output from the PowerShell console.
Default value\: false
    delimiter - The delimiter used to separate each property name from the property value in the output table.
Default value\: "\:".
    colDelimiter - The delimiter used to separate columns in the output table.
Default value\: ",".
    rowDelimiter - The delimiter used to separate rows in the output table.
Default value\: newline.
    hideResults - If this input is added and set to true, the "script", "stdout" and "warnings" results will be hidden. In case of operation failure the "returnResult" will no longer contain the Powershell exception stack-trace details, but the generic message\: "Could not execute powershell command". To use this input you need to manually add it from Studio Inputs tab of the operation, by clicking on the “Add Input” button.
Valid values\: true, false
Default value\: false

Results\:
    returnResult - The result of the script execution formatted as table or string depending on the returnTable input value as described above. In case of operation failure and "hideResults" is set to true, then this output will no longer contain the powershell exception stacktrace details.
    script - The actual PowerShell script that was run. This result might be useful when piping is enabled or you want to know exactly the script that was sent to be run on the PowerShell host. Please note that the operation adds "Out-String" command to the end of your script if returnTable input is set to false. This output will be hidden if "hideResults" input is set to true.
    objectsCount - The number of the PowerShell objects resulted from script execution (e.g. Get-Service will return the number of services found on the target host). This input is relevant only when returnTable is set to true. Otherwise, the value of this result will always be one, because the script returns a string message.
    warnings - A list of warnings that the cmdlets emit. If the cmdlets were executed without warnings, then this result will be an empty string. This output will be hidden if "hideResults" input is set to true.
    runspaceID - The runspace ID of the PowerShell runspace created during the execution of the operation.
    stdout - The result of the commands that succeeded in case the operation fails. In case of operation failure this output will be hidden if "hideResults" input is set to true.

Responses\:
    success - The Powershell script or cmdlet was executed successfully.
    failure - The command could not be executed.

Notes\:
1. In order to enable PowerShell scripts execution, run the following command\: Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned
2. When interacting with a Microsoft Exchange server, please use the generic Powershell operation available in the Business Application content pack, under /Library/Operations/Exchange/ folder, instead of loading the Exchange snap-in to this Powershell Script operation. This is a Microsoft Exchange design (http\://www.get-exchange.info/2012/12/30/powershell-scripting-for-exchange-server-some-tips/)
3. If the "hideResults" is set to false the "script" output will be added to the operation's output in which case the exact script that was executed will be displayed. Displaying the script could be a security risk when encrypted variables (which could be the sensitive data) are passed and referenced in the script, as they will be displayed unobfuscated. Also in case of operation failure the "stdout", "warnings" and "returnResults" outputs could contain the script with unobfuscated sensitive variables in it.
c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.2bb5cec3-d6f6-4d80-9006-6d1c8edcf663.prompt=/* Title\: PowerCLI Operation \: (Nucleus_automation_design_specification_v41) @Daway */ if ( 0 \=\= int(outReturnCode) ) { done(); put("errorCode","000") put("errorComponent","H"); did(true); }else if( doRetry() ) { did("other"); }else { put("errorCode","911") put("errorComponent","Acquire Lock error"+outFailureMessage); did(false) } // Define Function function done(){ println("Success running powerCLI"); println("Script\: "); printline("-",80); println(outScript); printline("\=",80); println("ReturnCode\: " + outReturnCode); println("Exception\: " + outException); println("host Name\: " + inHost); println("User Name\: " + inUsername); printline("-",80); println("Result\:"); println(outReturnResult); printline("\=",80); } function doRetry(){ var myRetry \= int(retry); myRetry -\= 1; println("Script\: "); printline("-",80); println(outScript); printline("\=",80); println("ReturnCode\: " + outReturnCode); println("Exception\: " + outException); println("host Name\: " + inHost); println("User Name\: " + inUsername); printline("-",80); println("Result\:"); println(outReturnResult); printline("\=",80); put("retry",myRetry); if(0 >\= myRetry){ return false; }else{ sleep(interval); return true; } put("errorCode","911"); } /////// Add-PSSnapin VMware.VimAutomation.Core Connect-VIServer -Server ${vCenterHost} -User ${vCenterUsername} -Password ${vCenterPassword} "-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------" ${PowerCliScript} "-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------" echo "done PowerCLI" c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.533602f8-4aa3-42cf-bea3-a0bfa4b2cfdb.description=Releases a lock with an id given by the value of the lockId input. 
Inputs\:
   lockId - the id of the lock, maximum 255 characters.

Responses\:
   success - the only response returned.

Results\:
   there are no results.

Notes\:
1) The operation only releases locks acquired by the current run. 
   It cannot release another run's locks.

2) The operation succeeds whether or not there is a lock held 
   by the current run with the supplied id.
c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.53baf2d5-d9c1-4e65-81f6-d241bb6de1a1.description=Attempts acquisition of a lock with an id given by the value of the lockId input. Inputs\: lockId - the id of the lock, maximum 255 characters. Responses\: success - if the lock has been successfully acquired. failure - if the lock could not be acquired. Result\: Code - 0 if the operation succeeds, 1 otherwise. Notes\: 1) The operation does not block waiting for a lock to become available. 2) The locks acquired by this operation are not reentrant. This means that once a lock is acquired by a run, all subsequent attempts at acquiring the same lock by the same run (or any other run) will fail. 3) Once a run terminates, all the locks that were acquired during its execution are automatically released. c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.568b84bb-2e2f-4f87-b84c-35a14661efad.callout=Action operation Check and Retry executes PowerShell scripts on a given host. -Inputs\: powerCliScript vCenterHost Script -Results\: errorCode errorComponent c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.88548c49-b3e2-4b1b-afb3-f3f4fee9bd48.callout=Attempts acquisition of a lock with an id given by the value of the lockId input. -Inputs\: lockId c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.92e72d14-5e09-4117-8059-8e0619e5b45e.description=
Get Error Codes

Inputs\:
errorCode\=911	
errorComponent\=${errorComponent}

Responses\:
success

c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.a684967b-ac13-4eda-a1d1-e7387190e649.callout=Run VMware PowerCLI /Nucleus Base/Library/TP Cloud/Operations/Nucleus Base/Run VMware PowerCLI c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.b44cad03-08e3-4801-8e82-e38926634930.description=
Accepts an object in the JavaScript Object Notation format (JSON) and and
creates and populates a flow variable for each member in the object.

The JSON format encodes objects as a set of unordered key/value pairs, which is
similar to a structure or map in other programming languages.  For example,
   { "city" \: "Palo Alto", 
     "state" \: "CA" }
is an object with two elements one with the name "city" having the value "Palo
Alto", and the other being the name "state" with the value "CA".  This operation
would create the flow variables city and state with the values "Palo Alto" and
"CA".

A optional prefix string can be specified that will be prepended to each flow
variable that is created.  For example, if the prefix is set to "my.", then
then the above object would result in the variables my.city (with value "Palo
Alto") and my.state (with value "CA").  This can be useful if flow variables
already exist with the given names to avoid overwriting their values.

JavaScript objects are useful for representing structured data, and are
especially when used within an array.  For example, an operation that retrieves
a set of incidents from an external system may return the entire list in one
array of incident objects.  The description of the enclosing folder,
/Library/Utility Operations/Container/JavaScript Objects has more examples, and
the JSON format is described completely at http\://www.json.org.

Inputs

   object
      The JavaScript object that will be converted into flow variables.  The
      operation will return a failure if the it is not a JavaScript object.
     i.e. \= { "city" \: "Palo Alto", "state" \: "CA","empty"\:"","noValue"\:"${noValue}" }
  
   list
     Check Variables list.  
    The operation will return a failure if the variable value is null in variable list.
     i.e. \=  city,empty,noValue
  delimiter
    The delimiter use on list. default is comma.
    i.e. \= ,
   prefix
      The prefix to prepend to each flow variable name that will be created.
      This is useful for creating unique variable names.

Responses

   success
      The flow variables were successfully created from the object.

   failure
      There was some error in processing the object, most likely because the
      object is not in valid JavaScript Object Notation.  You may wish to use a
      tool such as http\://www.jsonlint.com/ to help diagnose problems with
      JavaScript Object Notation.

Outputs

   A separate output will be created for each member of the object.  Each of
   these outputs may in turn contain another object or array.
c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.b576a0b0-c830-4b35-a043-9d13b2bc1153.callout=Check Inputs\: -Inputs\: object\: JSON format list\: check var list replaceEnterKeyInObject\:true -Results\: it's default return hidden errorCode & errorComponent, do not add them. c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.b6a3fa3e-91f1-46d5-b3dd-a65b71fbffa4.description=
This operation running scriptlet from Inputs, It can be used to script flow.
attention that do'not used Scriptlet tab, it need empty can be running script from Inputs script. 
This operation does not do anything. It can be used to filter flow variables by defining them as inputs and filtering them in the Results tab.

Inputs\:
    Scriptlet - write on javascript.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output.
    default this operation return errorCode and errorComponent that donot need add errorCode and errorComponent
    if you want add errorCode and errorComponent used below scriptlet, please refer Outputs sample
       errorCode  from returnResult scriptlet\:    scriptletResult \= scriptletContext.get("errorCode"); 
       errorComponent   from returnResult scriptlet\:   scriptletResult \= scriptletContext.get("errorComponent");
Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure   -  The operation failure as stated in the description.
    other -  The operation other as stated in the description.
Examples of usage \:

// This template shows how to access operation return data, inputs and context data 
// and how to set context data, responses and results. 

//convert to JSON object
jsObject \= JSON.parse({"var1"\:"value1"}); 
myValue \= jsonOBJ["var1"];

// To access an input simply refer to the input name from the Inputs panel.  For example\: 
myData \= inputName; 
 
// To get value associated with the context key myContextKey\: 
myContextData \= get("myContextKey"); 
 
// To get value associated with the context key myContextKey from the local context\: 
myContextData \= let("myContextKey"); 
 
// To access the return code from a command line or script (note it is a string and must 
// be converted into an integer for numeric processing)\: 
code \=getcode();
 
// To access the output from the operation (for example stdout)\: 
data \= getoutput() 
 
// To access the error string from the operation (for example stderr)\: 
error \=geterror();
 
// Other operations may have different result variables available.  To see the list for 
// a particular operation open the "Result from Field" dropdown on the Outputs tab 
 
// To set the response of the operation (must match one of the responses from the Responses tab)\: 
did(true); // did("success")
did(false); // did("failure")
did("other");
 
// To set the result of the operation 
print( "Your Result Here"); 
println( "Your Result Here"); 
// Use the context to hold data for use by other steps.  It is also helpful to place information 
// into the context to examine variables when developing and debugging scriptlets. 
// For example to place the OutputString information into a context key called 'Output'\: 
putglobal("Output", data); 
 
// Note that the Key and Value are both strings.  For example to place 'code' into the context\: 
putglobal("Code", code.toString()); 
 
// You can also place data into the local context, which means it will only be available to 
// the current flow, but not to its parent flow or other subflows.  To do this\: 
put("LocalVariable","LocalValue"); 

// You can use error function to throw eror message.
error("throw error message");
 
// sleep flow
sleep(interval)
c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.c387980c-ce1d-49dd-81b3-3f32072ca404.description=Releases a lock with an id given by the value of the lockId input. 
Inputs\:
   lockId - the id of the lock, maximum 255 characters.

Responses\:
   success - the only response returned.

Results\:
   there are no results.

Notes\:
1) The operation only releases locks acquired by the current run. 
   It cannot release another run's locks.

2) The operation succeeds whether or not there is a lock held 
   by the current run with the supplied id.
c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.c54621b0-0e8f-4576-83e1-a7e665026435.callout=\ (Nucleus_automation_design_specification_v41) \: Run Vmware PowerCLI for 3.18.4.14 FlexUp Disk @Daway c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.debc9725-a2a3-486f-bf78-71f73a465b4f.callout=Check acquisition lock -Inputs\: outCode -Results\: errorCode errorComponent -Response\: if have error to do retry c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.description=

c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.e8dabbf3-7c16-49b3-a1f3-b2e0f4cbb99c.callout=Attempts acquisition of a lock with an id given by the value of the lockId input. -Inputs\: lockId c070b068-d6e0-4d27-9970-387cd1dfb00c.f2064f9b-7711-4fc4-a158-391ab9b2048b.callout=Return error info\: -Inputs\: errorCode,errorComponent -Results(Flow OutPut) errorCode,errorComponent -Description Include errorCode List
flow.name: Run VMware PowerCLI

staticBinding.value:
## Have been include : Add-PSSnapin VMware.VimAutomation.Core try{ function CheckCmdHere() { "${checkCmdString}" } ## Begin: PowerCliScript @Daway ##================================= ## ( Nucleus_automation_design_specification_v41:) ##3.18.4.14: Call vCenter API to Expand Disk using ##================================= ## Begin: your PowerCLI Command here ##=========================================
get-vm
## Check Cmd Result need use this "********************************" if ($disk) { CheckCmdHere } "********************************"
##========================================== ## End: your PowerCLI Command here ## End: PowerCliScript }catch {echo "Error occured: $_"} #end try ##===============================

scriptlet.name: Step Check Input Varriable Null in Flow Run VMware PowerCLI (b44cad03-08e3-4801-8e82-e38926634930)

transition.name: failure(Checking Inputs to hide return errorCode)

scriptlet.name: Step Check&Retry Acquire Lock in Flow Run VMware PowerCLI (b6a3fa3e-91f1-46d5-b3dd-a65b71fbffa4)
Step PowerShell Script in Flow Run VMware PowerCLI (2bb5cec3-d6f6-4d80-9006-6d1c8edcf663)

staticBinding.value: Add-PSSnapin VMware.VimAutomation.Core Connect-VIServer -Server ${vCenterHost} -User ${vCenterUsername} -Password ${vCenterPassword} echo "start PowerCLI" "-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------" ${powerCliScript} "-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------" echo "done PowerCLI"
